Software Engineering Project - Course Guide

Project: Build a CQRS Synchronization between MongoDB (Write) and MySQL (Read)

Project Description

In this project, your team will design and build a system that keeps two different databases in sync:

  • MongoDB – the write database (for storing incoming data).
  • MySQL – the read database (for fast queries, reporting, or analytics).

You will use the CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation) pattern to separate writes (commands to MongoDB) from reads (queries on MySQL).

The main challenge: when data changes in MongoDB, those changes must quickly and reliably appear in MySQL. There are multiple ways to achieve this (see below), but in practice many systems use an event broker (e.g., RabbitMQ, Kafka, or NATS). For this project, you are free to choose your approach, but using a broker is recommended as it reflects industry best practice.

Goal

Deliver a working synchronization system that:

  • Detects changes in MongoDB.
  • Propagates these changes to MySQL using your chosen method (direct projector, change streams, outbox, or broker).
  • Keeps MySQL in sync in near real-time with minimal latency.
  • Includes a demo application with a domain and entities (DDD-inspired), so the CQRS pattern is demonstrated with realistic business logic.
  • Is easy to run locally (one-command startup with Docker).
  • Comes with clear documentation and examples so others can use it.

Context

In real-world systems, developers often separate:

  • Write models – optimized for saving domain data (e.g., MongoDB with aggregates/entities).
  • Read models – optimized for querying and reporting (e.g., MySQL projections).

This project gives you hands-on experience with data synchronization, event-driven systems, CQRS, and domain-driven design (DDD).

You can implement synchronization in several ways:

  1. Direct projector
  2. MongoDB Change Streams
  3. Transactional Outbox
  4. Event Broker (recommended)

Desired Outcome

A system that:

  • Keeps MySQL in sync with MongoDB writes.
  • Uses a domain model with entities and aggregates to make the CQRS pattern concrete.
  • Handles restarts and recoveries without losing data.
  • Runs locally with a single command (docker compose up).
  • Includes a demo app that shows synchronization in action (with realistic domain entities).
  • Is well documented, tested, and open-sourced on GitHub.

Functional Requirements

Must-Haves

  • Implement a domain model with entities (DDD-inspired) for the write side.
  • Detect changes in MongoDB.
  • Update MySQL projections using one of the chosen approaches.
  • Guarantee idempotent updates (no duplicates).
  • Provide recovery/replay so the system can catch up after restarts.
  • Deliver a demo app that shows synchronization flow.
  • Supply a Docker Compose setup (MongoDB, MySQL, and optional broker).
  • Document your setup, design choices, and usage.

Could haves

  • Add monitoring (metrics/logs, dashboard, or CLI).
  • Handle schema changes over time (e.g., adding/renaming fields).
  • Retry logic and dead-letter queue for failed events.
  • Introduce Event Sourcing: store domain events as the source of truth and rebuild projections from the event log.
  • Blue/green rebuild of the read database without downtime.

Non-Functional Requirements

  • Reliability: no data loss on restart; consistent updates.
  • Performance: synchronization within a few seconds.
  • Testability: ≥ 80% test coverage.
  • Observability: logs and metrics that show system state.
  • Reproducibility: one-command setup (Docker Compose).
  • Documentation: README and demo examples.

Research & Decision Making

You must research and justify your design decisions, including:

  • Which synchronization approach you chose (direct, change streams, outbox, or broker).
  • Why you did (or didn’t) use a broker.
  • How you guarantee ordering, idempotency, and recovery.
  • How you designed your domain model (entities/aggregates).
  • Whether you considered or experimented with event sourcing.
  • Record decisions as Architecture Decision Records (ADRs).

Project Requirements

  • Team size: 3 students.

  • Workflow: Agile/Scrum/Kanban.

  • Repository: GitHub with issues/boards and clear commits.

  • Setup: One-command run (docker compose up).

  • Environment: .env.example with safe defaults (no secrets).

  • CI/CD: Linting, testing, and building on PRs.

  • Deliverables:

    • Source code + documentation in GitHub.
    • Demo application with a domain model and entities.
    • Research report + ADRs.
    • Final presentation + reflection.

Assessment Criteria

  1. Research & Analysis – quality of investigation and justification of chosen approach.
  2. Functional Working – does the sync pipeline reliably keep MySQL in sync?
  3. Domain Model – does the demo app use a clear domain with entities/aggregates?
  4. Technical Quality – architecture, tests, recovery, observability.
  5. Documentation – clarity and accessibility of docs.
  6. Teamwork & Process – iterative work, collaboration, Git usage.
  7. Presentation & Reflection – ability to explain and defend your solution.

Definition of Done

The project is complete when:

  • Research completed and documented:
    • Research question, core concepts, and comparative analysis are written up
    • Experiments/benchmarks included where relevant
  • A working synchronization system exists (MongoDB → MySQL).
  • The chosen approach is documented and justified.
  • Must-have requirements are met, including a DDD-inspired domain model in the demo.
  • Tests pass with good coverage.
  • Documentation is complete
  • The system runs locally with one command.
  • A demo shows synchronization in action.
  • Final presentation and reflection delivered.
